author: Gabriel Moraes
title: Vendido pelo Cruzeiro, Arthur Gomes faz seu primeiro gol por novo clube; veja | O Tempo
text: Último jogador a ser negociado pelo [Cruzeiro](https://www.otempo.com.br/sports/cruzeiro), o atacante Arthur Gomes já balançou as redes pelo seu novo clube. Nessa quarta-feira (18/9), ele balançou as redes na Rússia atuando pelo Dínamo Moscou. O brasileiro marcou o segundo gol do time no empate por 2 a 2 com o Makhachkala, pela Copa da Rússia. Nos pênaltis, o Dínamo foi superado pelo adversário. Essa foi a segunda partida de Arthur pelo clube, e a segunda como titular. O Dínamo Moscou é o atual 4º colocado na Premier League Russa. Natural de Uberlândia, Arthur Gomes, de 26 anos, foi vendido pela Raposa no dia 7 de setembro por aproximadamente R$ 30 milhões e assinou contrato até junho de 2029. Com a camisa celeste foram 59 partidas, oito gols e cinco assistências.

author: Andrew McMunn
title: Firefighters rescue 71-year-old woman, her dog after her car falls off cliff
text:
HONOLULU (KHNL/Gray News) - Firefighters in Hawaii helped rescue a 71-year-old woman and her dog after their car went off a cliff in Maui Friday.
The Maui Department of Fire and Public Safety said emergency responders found the vehicle off the side of Kahekili Highway.
The rescuers used ropes to perform the rescue. They estimated the drop-off they were hanging over went 200 feet deep.
The rescue began just before noon, according to officials. Fire personnel used ropes to get to the victim and remove her from the car.
The highway was closed to allow first responders to work safely and has since reopened.
Officials said both the woman and the dog were rescued with no injuries.
Copyright 2024 KHNL/KGMB via Gray Media Group, Inc. All rights reserved.

author: The Hindu Bureau
title: Implementation of minimum wages and labour laws demanded for ASHA workers - The Hindu
text:
The All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC), on Thursday, criticised the working conditions of Accredited Social Health Activists (ASHAs) in Telangana, alleging that they are overworked and underpaid.
A delegation led by the Telangana State ASHA Workers’ Union submitted a petition to National Health Mission (NHM) chief programming officer Padmaja highlighting that ASHA workers, despite being hired on a result-based remuneration model, are forced to work beyond eight hours a day.
The union also pointed out the lack of social security measures, alleging that authorities are bypassing the implementation of mandatory benefits like Provident Fund (PF) and Employees’ State Insurance (ESI).
AITUC State Deputy General Secretary M. Narasimha demanded that minimum wages and labour laws be enforced for ASHA workers, who, he said, are unfairly treated with honorarium-based and fixed wages instead of proper remuneration.
In their memorandum, the union demanded a minimum wage of ₹26,000 per month, along with PF and ESI benefits. They also called for ₹10 lakh health and accident insurance coverage, a retirement benefit of ₹5 lakh, and weightage for ASHA workers in competitive examinations. Additionally, they urged the government to ensure that the families of deceased ASHAs are provided employment opportunities.
Published - March 27, 2025 08:03 pm IST
Read Comments Copy link Email Facebook Twitter Telegram LinkedIn WhatsApp Reddit READ LATER Remove SEE ALL PRINT

organizations.name: the Telangana State ASHA Workers’ Union
The All India Trade Union Congress

author: Mazepin
title: #15 El TSJA absuelve a un condenado en Córdoba por violar a su pareja al admitir ésta que lo denunció por celos
text:
Portada
mis comunidades
otras secciones
[#8](c8#c-8) Cuando esta misma justicia condena a los de alsasua, o a los titiriteros, o a los 6 de Zaragoza, etc., algunos aplaudís con las orejitas. Cuando pasa esto, ya es "justicia".
Pues la LIVG la firmaron TODOS, incluido el PP...
[#11](c11#c-11) ¿en base a que me incluyes en ese grupo? Vaya un “y tú más” más patético, que lástima que tu mejor defensa sea inventarte lo que pienso, que además de ser mentira es una bobada doble, porque además de ser una burda mentira haces como si una injusticia más otra injusticia sumasen justicia, cuando lo que suma es doble injusticia.
Que lamentable colega, en serio.
Todo el neofeminismo gira en torno a esta idea: puesto que las mujeres tienen un miedo constante a que un hombre las viole o las maltrate, la igualdad que se busca es que todos los hombres tengan miedo también a encontrarse con una loca que les denuncie y vayan a la cárcel.
Para ello se anulan los derechos que haya que anular, presunción de inocencia, necesidad de pruebas, etc...
De este modo se impone el criterio de una minoría de mujeres aterrorizadas sin justificación por los hombres que sólo quieren venganza disfrazada de una supuesta igualdad que es de todo menos eso.
Que vayan saliendo todos los mierdecillas que siempre dicen que es falso que basta la palabra de una mujer para que te comas 10 años de trullo... No, que sigan escondidos como ratas que son, me conformo con que les pase a ellos y a su familiares.
[#10](c10#c-10) Has escogido el caso más desafortunado posible para decir ese comentario. El tipo fue condenado, y solo ha conseguido la absolución cuando ELLA HA RECONOCIDO LA DENUNCIA FALSA.
Ha sido su palabra la que le metió en prisión y ha sido su palabra la que le ha sacado de ahí.
Hermano, date cuenta... al menos, en esta noticia, los mierdecillas esos de los que habla tienen más razón que tú
[#15](c15#c-15) no creo que sea así. Si los jueces lo condenaron fue unicamente por la palabra de la tiparraca... y esto le puede pasar a cualquiera, los jueces no tienen en cuenta más que eso. La confesión posterior, que puede ocurrir o no, dependiendo de muchos factores, lo unico que hace es dejarlo más claro todavía. Los jueces solo tienen en cuenta la palabra de una loca, porque no pueden existir otras pruebas al ser una denuncia falsa. Si la tipa no tiene remordimiento o teme simplemente las consecuencias de haber mentido al tribunal... el tio se come los 10 añitos.
[#0](c0#c-0) no es esta?
He podido leer la sentencia del TSJ que ha absuelto a este hombre de violación

author: Neha Mishra
title: Zoo implements ayurvedic methods to safeguard animals
text: New Delhi : Delhi Zoo authorities are using ayurvedic methods, including neem oil, turmeric and quicklime, to keep the animals healthy and free from bacterial and viral infections during the rainy season. As the monsoon season sets in, Delhi Zoo is taking innovative steps to ensure the health and safety of its animals by incorporating traditional ayurvedic methods.\"The monsoon has entered the capital and we have to take all necessary measures to keep the animals healthy and safe during this season. We will use some Indian home remedies like neem oil, which will help protect the animals from common biting insects, including mosquitoes, biting midges and fleas,\" Delhi Zoo Director Sanjeet Kumar told PTI.Neem oil acts as an herbal disinfectant and fly repellent, said Kumar, turmeric, known for its anti-inflammatory and healing properties, will be used to treat itchy skin conditions, infections and wounds. Turmeric dust will be applied to lesions and foot sores to expedite healing, he said. Heavy rains often lead to waterlogging in certain parts of the zoo which create breeding grounds for mosquitoes.To counter this, quicklime (chuna) will be sprinkled in these areas to prevent mosquito proliferation. \"We are using quicklime in waterlogged spots to stop the growth of mosquitoes and keep our animals safe,\" the official said. After the heavy rains that lashed the national capital on Friday, recording 228.1 mm of rainfall in just 24 hours — the highest in June since 1936 — the Delhi Zoo was also affected.A power failure occurred when floodwaters breached the zoo's boundary wall from the Sundernagar side, inundating the substation area and causing damage to the transformer. This incident affected animal enclosures, administrative offices and staff quarters. Referring to this situation, Kumar said that measures have been taken to prevent a recurrence.

author: David Laurell
title: David Laurell: Conundrum Theatre Company's 'Guys and Dolls' Still Resonates Today
text:
With last evening’s opening night of “Guys and Dolls” looming, the show’s crew spent this past week fine-tuning the production’s scenery construction, wardrobe, lighting and sound, while the cast polished their acting, singing and dancing, and the band perfected their musical performances.
Staged by Burbank’s Conundrum Theatre Company at Colia Productions, the company transformed the facility’s empty soundstage into a working theater complete with tiered seating for the audience before scenically enhancing the stage with sets of New York City’s Hot Box Club and Save-A-Soul Mission, and a steamy nightclub of Havana, Cuba.
“Unlike staging a production at an actual theater, when we first came in here, we only had four walls and a light grid,” said the show’s director Spencer Scruggs. “That was both fun in that we were not constrained by a theater’s design, but also very challenging in that we literally had to create everything from nothing.”
Crediting the production’s set designer Vega Sherman-Seitz, production manager Vicky Yvonne and choreographer Jonathan Blake Flemings for making their combined vision for the show a reality, Scruggs said his confident reliance on the team freed him up to work with his actors, singers, dancers and musicians, who were only cast in July.
“I have really enjoyed working with this cast,” said Scruggs. “Each one of the leads has been able to bring their own distinctive characterizations into their roles–blending their own concept of who the characters are into what audiences who are familiar with the play or have seen the film have come to expect.”
During a break in a rehearsal days before the show opened, the production’s principals — Carter Santos who plays Sky Masterson, Wayne Remington who takes on the role of Nathan Detroit, Bouket Fingerhut who portrays Miss Adelaide and Abhaya Krishnan-Jha who assumes the part of Sergeant Sister Sarah Brown–discussed their thoughts on the show and their characters.
“It’s a story of the past told by people of today,” said Remington, who considers Detroit to be “a complicated guy.”
“It’s clear that he really loves Adelaide, but it’s equally clear that he is afraid of commitment,” opined Remington, who has appeared in several community theater productions including Conundrum’s “Rent” in which he played Mark Cohen, and “Seussical the Musical” where he took on the role of the mayor of Whoville.
Fingerhut, the most experienced of the principal cast, produced Conundrum’s “Legally Blonde” and has appeared on stage in many well-known shows such as “West Side Story” and “Gypsy.”
Viewing “Guys and Dolls” as “a rom-com with heart and charm,” Fingerhut said she sees Adelaide as a woman filled with love and compassion.
“She sees the best in people, even in those who show her their worst side,” she said.
Carter Santos, a transplant from Rhode Island who has a commanding stage presence, has been a featured performer with Disney Cruise Line and has appeared on stage as Ren McCormack in “Footloose,” Davey in “Newsies” and Tulsa in “Gypsy.”
He broke out laughing when asked about playing Sky Masterson.
“Sky is an eccentric lover boy,” he exclaimed. “He doesn’t leave Sarah for one simple reason – he loves her!”
Playing Sky’s love interest, Krishnan-Jha said she sees Sarah as a young woman brought up in a world where you were to never question things, especially your religion.
“She is devout and dedicated to her religious beliefs,” said Krishnan-Jha. “However, she is also unsure about things, and the more she grows and blossoms, the more her beliefs are challenged, especially during her time in Havana,” she added with a sly smile.
While she sees a bit of herself in Sarah, Krishnan-Jha said she is thankful that the director and producer were not bound by traditional typecasting.
“I would not be the archetypal type to be cast in the role of Sarah,” said Krishnan-Jha, a software engineer. “I never thought I would get to play an ingénue. That is why I read the script and auditioned before watching the movie. I didn’t want to have any preconceived thoughts that would get in the way of my interpretation of who Sarah is.”
A classic musical that debuted on Broadway 74 years ago, most people today are familiar with “Guys and Dolls” from the 1955 MGM film that starred Marlon Brando, Jean Simmons, Frank Sinatra and Vivian Blaine.
The story, adapted from the 1930s writings of Damon Runyon, was brought to the stage by playwrights Jo Swerling and Abe Burrows. With music and lyrics by Frank Loesser, the musical score is considered one of the most beloved in the history of American theatre.
The show takes place in New York sometime between the two World Wars. In true Runyonesque style, it takes audiences into a world of sinners and saints, from the gangsters and gamblers of the streets and the showgirls of the Hot Box Club to the missionaries of the Save-A-Soul Mission.
“My style is to direct from a perspective of relationships,” Scruggs said during a rehearsal break. “My goal is to have my cast develop their characters through the relationships they have with themselves, their characters, with the other characters and with a moment in time.”
Although the characters may be dated by their distinctive dialogue and wardrobe (beautifully crafted for this production by costume designer Morgan Cordova-Stuart), the show’s theme–that it’s impossible for anyone to be happy living in a world dominated by extremist thinking–is, perhaps, more relevant in today’s polarized world than it was when the play first hit the boards.
“Guys and Dolls” will run tonight and tomorrow night, and then next Friday, Saturday and Sunday at Colia Productions, 1208 West Isabel Street Burbank. There is free self-parking and wheelchair accessibility. Tickets are $30 for general admission and $40 and $45 for preferred seating, which includes sitting at tables on the stage, a 30-minute immersive pre-show and exclusive commemorative merchandise. The show includes mild swearing, alcohol consumption and gambling.
For tickets or more information on the Conundrum Theatre Company, their upcoming productions, auditions and contribution and sponsorship opportunities, visit
www.conundrumtheatreco.com.
DAVID LAURELL may be reached by email at or (818) 563-1007.
